Is public transportation operating? Yes.  Limited public transportation within cities with strict limitations is operating.   In the Buenos Aires metropolitan area, only essential workers with a circulation permit may board public transportation. These regulations are likely to remain in place for the duration of the quarantine order. Travelers should expect further travel disruptions with little notice.  Long-haul intercity transportation options are restricted to essential workers as outlined in the national quarantine order as well as those seeking medical treatment.  The Government of Argentina has also indicated that U.S. citizens may use these transportation options to connect with confirmed international departure opportunities from Buenos Aires.  All passengers are required to have a valid Certificado Único de Circulación to travel and should consult transportation provider and local officials regarding travel eligibility and additional requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://ar.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    It is important to note GoB officials have confirmed that the list of Red zones does not mean the areas are or will be under lockdown restrictions.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - **Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.**  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      IN GENERAL: COVID19-related restrictions seem be removed, although with strict adherence to mask wearing.  Dhaka Tribune: "On October 31, the Cabinet Division sent notices to all public offices of the country, asking them to restrict entry and to refuse service to anyone without a mask. The notice further said masks have been made compulsory for all offices, courts, shopping malls, bazaars, state or government buildings and **social events**."  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122215536/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/11/02/no-restriction-on-public-movement-to-curb-second-wave-of-covid-19    Nov 12, reuters.com: "“The decision has been taken considering the second wave... We can’t play with the lives of our children,” said a senior official of the education ministry, who declined to be named. **The government however, has lifted most other restrictions**"  source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122212335if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bangladesh-educati/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave-idUSKBN27S26A

The Department of Transport advises ALL bus operators and the public that the Minister of Health and Wellness Hon. Michel Chebat has announced a 21-day curfew for the entire country, which will commence on Saturday, 28th November, 2020 from 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m.    Therefore, only those bus operators with a valid Road Service Permit with runs starting from 5:15 a.m. which are to return back to their original point of departure before 8:30 p.m. will be allowed to operate.    Special written permission must be granted by the Department of Transport to those bus operators who will need to operate outside of their normal bus schedule without interfering with the existing bus schedules within non-curfew hours.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201128062025/https://ambergriscaye.com/forum/ubbthreads.php/topics/546512/notice-to-all-bus-operators-on-curfew.html

The federal and state governments call for unnecessary travel to be avoided in general. This also includes unnecessary journeys in public transport. Please wear an everyday mask on the S-Bahn and trains, in the train station, on the platform and at the stops as well as on the airport premises and on the plane. The minimum distance of 1.5 meters to travelers and staff should always be observed. Deutsche Bahn provides many tips on safe travel on its website. Unnecessary queues, e.g. B. in front of the on-board toilet can be avoided. The respective national hygiene regulations apply when getting on and off and at the airports. In general, please adhere to the rules of conduct that are summarized in the AHA formula (distance, hygiene rules, everyday mask). In this way, everyone can make a contribution while traveling to contain the spread of the new type of coronavirus. This formula is supplemented by A for app (the Corona warning app helps to break chains of infection) and L for ventilation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207220918/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/informieren/alltag-gestalten/

A curfew is in effect in 29 of Algeria’s 48 provinces, including in Algiers, where the curfew is from 11 pm to 6 am. Curfews are constantly being reviewed and revised and the curfew may be more restrictive in certain provinces or in certain areas of the provinces above for short periods of time as the health situation develops. "Under the current border control policy, all travelers from abroad, Japanese or foreign, are asked not to use public transportation for the entirety of their two-week quarantine period, including immediately after arrival, due to the risk of spreading the virus.  ...  In an apparent compromise meant to ease rules on public transportation, the government is now reportedly considering whether to allow travelers to use trains to depart airports after all — on condition that they will be segregated into cars set aside exclusively for them, according to the Nikkei business daily.    The transport ministry is also now arranging for Airport Transport Service Co. to run shuttle buses from Narita and Haneda airports to some 12 hotels within Tokyo to relieve travelers of expensive taxi fares, ministry official Keita Yamamoto said. If all goes well, the service is set to start on Dec. 16, according to the airport bus operator."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207075227/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/12/07/national/inbound-travelers-japan-public-transit/

estricted stations to open.  • Restricted capacity of up to 30% based on calculation of at least 9m2 per person.  • 1.5m physical distance between passengers and staff at all times, and in all areas (including transit and waiting areas). According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. Due to the current internal conflict, increased restrictions and health screenings have been observed at certain transit points. Transit points along land borders are partially open for the entry and exit of passengers. Authorities at Al’Wadeeah land border allow stranded Yemenis to enter Yemen after a temperature check. Sana’a International Airport has reopened for humanitarian flights. no clear policy but any travel is restricted due to the civil war     https://web.archive.org/web/20201029155117/https://displacement.iom.int/yemen       https://displacement.iom.int/system/tdf/reports/20201021_COVID19_DTM%20Yemen%20Mobility%20Restrictions%20Dashboard%20DRAFT_%2314.pdf?file=1&type=node&id=9977

Per US embassy, Public rail, minibus taxi, and bus services have resumed at reduced levels subject to social distancing and mandatory use of face masks for passengers and drivers.  Minibus taxis and buses must reduce their maximum licensed passenger seating capacity to 70% a vehicle, e-hailing services that are licensed to carry up to four passengers are limited to carrying 50% of their permissible passenger carrying capacity.  Transport services are required to provide adequate sanitizers for washing of hands of all passengers.  Operators must ensure that their vehicles are sanitised before picking up and after dropping off passengers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201129221233/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
